content i ll surgeon s second serv man so will i third serv man i will see what physic tavern afford exeunt servant mayor c warwick accept thi scroll most graciou sovereign which right richard plantagenet we do exhibit your majesti gloucest well urg d my lord warwick sweet princ if your grace mark everi circumst you have great reason do richard right especi those occas eltham place i told your majesti king henri those occas uncl were forc therefor my love lord our pleasur is that richard be restor hi blood warwick let richard be restor hi blood so shall hi father s wrong be recompen d winchest as will rest so willeth winchest king henri if richard will be true not that alon but all whole inherit i give that doth belong unto hous york whenc you spring lineal descent plantagenet thi humbl servant vow obedi humbl servic till point death king henri stoop then set your knee against my foot reguerdon that duti done i girt thee valiant sword york rise richard like true plantagenet rise creat princ duke york plantagenet so thrive richard as thi foe may fall as my duti spring so perish they that grudg one thought against your majesti all welcom high princ mighti duke york somerset asid perish base princ ignobl duke york gloucest now will it best avail your majesti cross sea be crown d franc presenc king engend love hi subject hi loyal friend as it disanim hi enemi king henri when gloucest say word king henri goe friendli counsel cut off mani foe gloucest your ship alreadi are readi sennet flourish exeunt all but exet exet ay we may march england or franc not see what is like ensu thi late dissens grown betwixt peer burn feign ash forg d love will last break flame as fest red member rot but degre till bone flesh sinew fall away so will thi base enviou discord breed now i fear that fatal propheci which time henri nam d fifth wa mouth everi suck babe that henri born monmouth should win all henri born windsor should lose all which is so plain that exet doth wish hi day may finish ere that hapless time exit scene 2 franc rouen enter la pucel disgui d four soldier dress like countrymen sack their back pucel these are citi gate gate rouen which our polici must make breach take heed be wari how you place your word talk like vulgar sort market men that come gather money their corn if we have entranc as i hope we shall that we find sloth watch but weak i ll sign give notic our friend that charl dauphin may encount them first soldier our sack shall be mean sack citi we be lord ruler rouen therefor we ll knock knock watch qui est la pucel paysan pauvr gen de franc poor market folk that come sell their corn watch enter go market bell is rung pucel now rouen i ll shake thi bulwark ground la pucel c enter town enter charl bastard alencon reignier forc charl saint deni bless thi happi stratagem onc again we ll sleep secur rouen bastard here ent red pucel her practis now she is there how will she specifi here is best safest passag alencon thrust torch yonder tower which onc discern d show that her mean is no way that weak which she ent red enter la pucel top thrust torch burn pucel behold thi is happi wed torch that joineth rouen unto her countrymen but burn fatal talbotit exit bastard see nobl charl beacon our friend burn torch yonder turret stand charl now shine it like comet reveng prophet fall all our foe alencon defer no time be speaker talbot dare ye come forth meet us field pucel belik your lordship take us then fool tri if that our own be our or no talbot i speak not that rail hecat but unto thee alencon rest will ye like soldier come fight it alencon signior no talbot signior hang base mulet franc like peasant foot boy do they keep wall dare not take arm like gentlemen pucel away captain let s get us wall talbot mean no good hi look god b uy my lord we came but tell you that we are here exeunt wall talbot there will we be too ere it be long or els reproach be talbot s greatest fame vow burgundi honour thi hous prick d public wrong sustain d franc either get town again or die i as sure as english henri live as hi father here wa conqueror as sure as thi late betray town great coeur de lion s heart wa buri so sure i swear get town or die burgundi my vow are equal partner thi vow talbot but ere we go regard thi die princ valiant duke bedford come my lord we will bestow you some better place fitter sick crazi age bedford lord talbot do not so dishonour me here will i sit wall rouen will be partner your weal or woe burgundi courag bedford let us now persuad you bedford not be gone henc onc i read that stout pendragon hi litter sick came field vanquish hi foe methink i should reviv soldier heart becaus i ever found them as myself talbot undaunt spirit die breast then be it so heaven keep old place therein some expert offic then depart pari king there young henri hi nobl lie burgundi what lord talbot pleaseth burgundi talbot but yet we go let s not forget nobl duke bedford late decea d but see hi exequi fulfil d rouen braver soldier never couch lanc gentler heart did never sway court but king mightiest potent must die that s end human miseri exeunt scene 3 plain near rouen enter charl die eye see see pine maladi franc behold wound most unnatur wound which thou thyself hast given her woeful breast o turn thi edg sword anoth way strike those that hurt hurt not those that help one set foot onc franc fashion d thee that instrument ill who then but english henri will be lord thou be thrust like fugit call we mind mark but thi proof wa not duke orlean thi foe wa he not england return return thou wander lord charl rest will take thee their arm burgundi i am vanquish these haughti word her have batt red me like roar cannon shot made me almost yield my knee forgiv me countri sweet countrymen lord accept thi hearti kind embrac my forc my power men are your so farewel talbot i ll no longer trust thee pucel done like frenchman asid turn turn again charl welcom brave duke thi you would exeunt act iv scene 1 park palac enter king gloucest winchest york suffolk somerset warwick talbot exet governor pari other gloucest lord bishop set crown hi head winchest god save king deliv d my hand writ your grace th duke burgundi talbot shame duke burgundi thee i vow d base knight when i did meet thee next tear garter thi craven s leg pluck it off which i have done becaus unworthili thou wast instal that high degre pardon me princ henri rest thi dastard battl patay when but all i wa six thousand strong that french were almost ten one we met or that stroke wa given like trusti squir did run away which assault we lost twelv hundr men myself diver gentlemen besid were there surpri d taken prison then judg great lord if i have done amiss or that such coward ought wear thi ornament knighthood yea or no gloucest say truth thi fact wa infam ill beseem ani common man much more knight captain leader talbot when first thi order wa ordain d my lord knight garter were nobl birth valiant virtuou full haughti courag such as were grown credit war not fear death nor shrink distress but alway resolut most extrem he then that is not furnish d thi sort doth but usurp sacr name knight profan thi most honour order should if i were worthi be judg be quit degrad like hedg born swain that doth presum boast gentl blood king henri stain thi countrymen thou hear st thi doom be pack therefor thou that wast knight henceforth we banish thee pain death exit fastolf now my lord protector view letter sent our uncl duke burgundi gloucest view superscript what mean hi grace that he hath boy mount my swiftest hors i ll direct thee how thou shalt escap sudden flight come dalli not be gone john is my name talbot am i your son shall i fli o if you love my mother dishonour not her honour name make bastard slave me world will say he is not talbot s blood that base fled when nobl talbot stood talbot fli reveng my death if i be slain john he that fli so will ne er return again talbot if we both stay we both are sure die john then let me stay father do you fli your loss is great so your regard should be my worth unknown no loss is known me my death french can littl boast your they will you all hope are lost flight cannot stain honour you have won but mine it will that no exploit have done you fled vantag everi one will swear but if i bow they ll say it wa fear there is no hope that ever i will stay if first hour i shrink run away here my knee i beg mortal rather than life preserv d infami talbot shall all thi mother s hope lie one tomb john ay rather than i ll shame my mother s womb talbot my bless i command thee go john fight i will but not fli foe talbot part thi father may be sav d thee john no part him but will be shame me talbot thou never hadst renown nor canst not lose it john ye your renown name shall flight abus it talbot thi father s charg shall clear thee that stain john you cannot wit me be slain if death be so appar then both fli talbot leav my follow here fight die my age wa never taint such shame john shall my youth be guilti such blame no more can i be sever your side than can yourself yourself yourself twain divid stay go do what you will like do i live i will not if my father die talbot then here i take my leav thee fair son born eclips thi life thi afternoon come side side togeth live die soul soul franc heaven fli exeunt scene 6 field battl alarum excurs wherein john talbot is hemm d talbot rescu him talbot saint georg victori fight soldier fight regent hath talbot broke hi word left us rage franc hi sword where is john thou gav st new date talbot when dauphin s crest thi sword struck fire it warm d thi father s heart proud desir bold fac d victori then leaden age quicken d youth spleen warlik rage beat down alencon orlean burgundi pride gallia rescu thee ire bastard orlean that drew blood thee my boy had maidenhood thi first fight i soon encount interchang blow i quickli shed some hi bastard blood disgrac bespok him thu contamin base misbegotten blood i spill thine mean right poor that pure blood mine which thou didst forc talbot my brave boy here purpos bastard destroy came strong rescu speak thi father s care art thou not weari john how dost thou fare wilt thou yet leav battl boy fli now thou art seal d son chivalri fli reveng my death when i am dead help one stand me littl stead o too much folli is it well i wot hazard all our live one small boat if i day die not frenchmen s rage morrow i shall die mickl age me they noth gain if i stay ti but short ning my life one day thee thi mother die our household s name my death s reveng thi youth england s fame all these more we hazard thi stay all these are sav d if thou wilt fli away john sword orlean hath not made me smart these word your draw life blood my heart that advantag bought such shame save paltri life slay bright fame young talbot old talbot fli coward hors that bear me fall die like me peasant boy franc be shame s scorn subject mischanc sure all glori you have won if i fli i am not talbot s son then talk no more flight it is no boot if son talbot die talbot s foot talbot then follow thou thi desp rate sire crete thou icaru thi life me is sweet if thou wilt fight fight thi father s side commend prov d let s die pride exeunt scene 7 anoth part field alarum excurs enter old talbot led servant talbot where is my other life mine own is gone o where s young talbot where is valiant john triumphant death smear d captiv young talbot s valour make me smile thee when he perceiv d me shrink my knee hi bloodi sword he brandish d me like hungri lion did commenc rough deed rage stern impati but when my angri guardant stood alon tend ring my ruin assail d none dizzi ey d furi great rage heart suddenli made him my side start clust ring battl french that sea blood my boy did drench hi overmount spirit there die my icaru my blossom hi pride enter soldier bear bodi john talbot servant o my dear lord lo where your son is born talbot thou antic death which laugh st us here scorn anon thi insult tyranni coupl bond perpetu two talbot wing lither sky thi despit shall scape mortal o thou whose wound becom hard favour death speak thi father ere thou yield thi breath brave death speak he will or no imagin him frenchman thi foe poor boy he smile methink as who should say had death been french then death had die day come come lay him hi father s arm my spirit can no longer bear these harm soldier adieu i have what i would have now my old arm are young john talbot s grave die enter charl alencon burgundi bastard la pucel forc charl had york somerset brought rescu we should have found bloodi day thi bastard how young whelp talbot s rage wood did flesh hi puni sword frenchmen s blood pucel onc i encount red him thu i said thou maiden youth be vanquish d maid but proud majest high scorn he answer d thu young talbot wa not born be pillag giglot wench so rush bowel french he left me proudli as unworthi fight burgundi doubtless he would have made nobl knight see where he lie inhears arm most bloodi nurser hi harm bastard hew them piec hack their bone asund whose life wa england s glori gallia s wonder charl o no forbear that which we have fled life let us not wrong it dead enter sir william luci attend french herald preced luci herald conduct me dauphin s tent know who hath obtain d glori day charl what submiss messag art thou sent luci submiss dauphin ti mere french word we english warrior wot not what it mean i come know what prison thou hast ta en survey bodi dead charl prison ask st thou blown lie here our feet luci is talbot slain frenchmen s onli scourg your kingdom s terror black nemesi o were mine eye ban bullet turn d that i rage might shoot them your face o that i could but can these dead life it were enough fright realm franc were but hi pictur left you here it would amaz proudest you all give me their bodi that i may bear them henc give them burial as beseem their worth pucel i think thi upstart is old talbot s ghost he speak such proud command spirit god s sake let him have them keep them here they would but stink putrefi air charl go take their bodi henc luci i ll bear them henc but their ash shall be rear d phoenix that shall make all franc afeard charl so we be rid them do them what thou wilt now pari thi conquer vein all will be our now bloodi talbot s slain exeunt act v scene 1 london palac sennet enter king gloucest exet king henri have you peru d letter pope emperor earl armagnac gloucest i have my lord their intent is thi they humbl sue unto your excel have godli peac conclud realm england franc king henri how doth your grace affect their motion gloucest well my good lord as onli mean stop effus our christian blood stablish quiet everi side king henri ay marri uncl i alway thought it wa both impiou unnatur that such imman bloodi strife should reign professor one faith gloucest besid my lord sooner effect surer bind thi knot amiti earl armagnac near knit charl man great author franc proffer hi onli daughter your grace marriag larg sumptuou dowri king henri marriag uncl ala my year are young fitter is my studi my book than wanton dallianc paramour yet call th ambassador as you pleas so let them have their answer everi one i shall be well content ani choic tend god s glori my countri s weal enter cardin s habit beaufort papal legat two ambassador exet what is my lord winchest instal d call d unto cardin s degre then i perceiv that will be verifi henri fifth did sometim prophesi if onc he come be cardin he ll make hi cap co equal crown king henri my lord ambassador your sever suit have been consid d debat your purpos is both good reason therefor are we certainli resolv d draw condit friendli peac which my lord winchest we mean shall be transport present franc gloucest proffer my lord your master i have inform d hi high so larg as like ladi s virtuou gift her beauti valu her dower he doth intend she shall be england asid now winchest will not submit i trow or be inferior proudest peer humphrey gloucest thou shalt well perceiv that neither birth or author bishop will be overborn thee i ll either make thee stoop rever hand i kiss these finger etern peac lay them gentli thi tender side who art thou say that i may honour thee margaret margaret my name daughter king king napl whoso er thou art suffolk earl i am suffolk am i call d be not offend natur s miracl thou art allot be ta en me so doth swan her downi cygnet save keep them prison underneath her wing yet if thi servil usag onc offend go be free again as suffolk s friend she is go o stay asid i have no power let her pass my hand would free her but my heart say no as play sun glassi stream twinkl anoth counterfeit beam so seem thi gorgeou beauti mine eye fain would i woo her yet i dare not speak i ll call pen ink write my mind fie de la pole disabl not thyself hast not tongu is she not here thi prison wilt thou be daunt woman s sight ay will deni thi suit thou make trial her love margaret whi speak st thou not what ransom must i pay suffolk asid she s beauti therefor be woo d she is woman therefor be won margaret wilt thou accept gone while as silli owner good weep them wring hi hapless hand shake hi head trembl stand aloof while all is shar d all is born away readi starv dare not touch hi own so york must sit fret bite hi tongu while hi own land are bargain d sold methink realm england franc ireland bear that proport my flesh blood as did fatal brand althaea burnt unto princ s heart calydon anjou main both given unto french cold news me i had hope franc even as i have fertil england s soil day will come when york shall claim hi own therefor i will take nevil part make show love proud duke humphrey when i spi advantag claim crown that s golden mark i seek hit nor shall proud lancast usurp my right nor hold sceptr hi childish fist nor wear diadem hi head whose church like humour fit not crown then york be still awhil till time do serv watch thou wake when other be asleep pri secret state till henri surfeit joy love hi new bride england s dear bought queen humphrey peer be fall n jar then will i rais aloft milk white rose whose sweet smell air shall be perfum d my standard bear arm york grappl hous lancast forc perforc i ll make him yield crown whose bookish rule hath pull d fair england down exit scene ii duke gloucest s hous enter duke hi wife eleanor duchess whi droop my lord like ripen d corn hang head cere plenteou load whi doth great duke humphrey knit hi brow as frown favour world whi are thine eye fix d sullen earth gaze that which seem dim thi sight what see st thou there king henri s diadem encha d all honour world if so gaze grovel thi face thi head be circl same put forth thi hand reach gloriou gold what is t too short i ll lengthen it mine have both togeth heav d it we ll both togeth lift our head heaven never more abas our sight so low as vouchsaf one glanc unto ground gloucest o nell sweet nell if thou dost love thi lord banish canker ambiti thought may that thought when i imagin ill against my king nephew virtuou henri be my last breath thi mortal world my troublou dream thi night doth make me sad duchess what dream d my lord tell me i ll requit it sweet rehears my morn s dream gloucest methought thi staff mine offic badg court wa broke twain whom i have forgot but as i think it wa th cardin piec broken wand were plac d head edmund duke somerset william de la pole first duke suffolk thi wa my dream what it doth bode god know duchess tut thi wa noth but argument that he that break stick gloucest s grove shall lose hi head hi presumpt but list me my humphrey my sweet duke methought i sat seat majesti cathedr church westminst that chair where king queen were crown d where henri dame margaret kneel d me my head did set diadem gloucest nay eleanor then must i chide outright presumptu dame ill nurtur d eleanor art thou not second woman realm i care wert thou thenc wilder is popul enough so suffolk had thi heavenli compani where thou art there is world itself everi sever pleasur world where thou art not desol i can no more live thou joy exil my soul s treasur whi onli suffolk mourn i not thee southern cloud contend tear their earth s increas mine my sorrow now get thee henc king thou know st is come if thou be found me thou art but dead suffolk if i depart thee i cannot live thi sight die what were it els but like pleasant slumber thi lap here could i breath my soul air as mild gentl as cradl babe die mother s dug it lip where thi sight i should be rage mad cri thee close mine eye have thee thi lip stop my mouth so shouldst thou either turn my fli soul or i should breath it so thi bodi then it liv d sweet elysium die thee were but die jest thee die were tortur more than death o let me stay befal what may befal queen away though part be fret corros it is appli death wound franc sweet suffolk let me hear thee whereso er approach is seen so terribl warwick beaufort it is thi sovereign speak thee cardin bring me unto my trial when you will die he not hi bed where should he die can i make men live whe er they will or no enter cade cade fie ambit fie myself that have sword yet am readi famish these five day have i hid me these wood durst not peep all countri is laid me but now am i so hungri that if i might have leas my life thousand year i could stay no longer wherefor brick wall have i climb d thi garden see if i can eat grass or pick sallet anoth while which is not amiss cool man s stomach thi hot weather i think thi word sallet wa born do me good mani time but sallet my brain pain had been cleft brown bill mani time when i have been dri brave march it hath serv d me instead quart pot drink now word sallet must serv me feed enter iden iden lord who would live turmoil court may enjoy such quiet walk as these thi small inherit my father left me contenteth me worth monarchi i seek not wax great other wane or gather wealth i care not what envi sufficeth that i have maintain my state send poor well pleas my gate cade here s lord soil come seiz me stray enter hi fee simpl leav ah villain thou wilt betray me get thousand crown king carri my head him but i ll make thee eat iron like ostrich swallow my sword like great pin ere thou i part iden whi rude companion whatso er thou be i know thee not whi then should i betray thee is t not enough break my garden like thief come rob my ground climb my wall spite me owner but thou wilt brave me these sauci term cade brave thee ay best blood that ever wa broach d beard thee too look me well i have eat no meat these five day yet come thou thi five men if i do not leav you all as dead as door nail i pray god i may never eat grass more iden nay it shall ne er be said while england stand that alexand iden esquir kent took odd combat poor famish d man oppos thi steadfast gaze eye mine see if thou canst outfac me thi look set limb limb thou art far lesser thi hand is but finger my fist thi leg stick compar thi truncheon my foot shall fight all strength thou hast if mine arm be heav air thi grave is digg d alreadi earth as word whose great answer word let thi my sword report what speech forbear cade my valour most complet champion that ever i heard steel if thou turn edg or cut not burli bon d clown chine beef ere thou sleep thi sheath i beseech god my knee thou mayst be turn d hobnail here they fight cade fall o i am slain famin no other hath slain me let ten thousand devil come against me give me but ten meal i have lost i d defi them all wither garden be henceforth buri place all that do dwell thi hous becaus unconqu soul cade is fled iden is t cade that i have slain that monstrou traitor sword i will hallow thee thi thi deed hang thee o er my tomb when i am dead ne er shall thi blood be wipe thi point but thou shalt wear it as herald s coat emblaz honour that thi master got cade iden farewel be proud thi victori tell kent outstretch arm yet part but shadow hi hand what wa it you that would be england s king wa t you that revel d our parliament made preachment your high descent where are your mess son back you now that valiant clifford hi rapier s point made issu bosom boy if thine eye can water hi death i give thee thi dri thi cheek withal ala poor york but that i hate thee deadli i should lament thi miser state i prithe griev make me merri york what hath thi fieri heart so parch d thine entrail that not tear can fall rutland s death whi art thou patient man thou shouldst be mad i make thee mad do mock thee thu stamp rave fret that i may sing danc thou wouldst be fee d i see make me sport york cannot speak unless he wear crown crown york lord bow low him hold you hi hand whilst i do set it put paper crown hi head ay marri sir now look he like king ay thi is he that took king henri s chair thi is he wa hi adopt heir but how is it that great plantagenet is crown d so soon broke hi solemn oath as i bethink me you should not be king till our king henri had shook hand death will you pale your head henri s glori rob hi templ diadem now hi life against your holi oath o ti fault too too off crown crown hi head whilst we breath take time do him dead clifford that is my offic my father s sake queen margaret nay stay let s hear orison he make york she wolf franc but wors than wolv franc whose tongu more poison than adder s tooth how ill beseem is it thi sex triumph like amazonian trull their woe whom fortun captiv but that thi face is visard like unchang made impud use evil deed i would assay proud queen make thee blush tell thee whenc thou cam st whom deriv d were shame enough shame thee wert thou not shameless thi father bear type king napl both sicil jerusalem yet not so wealthi as english yeoman hath that poor monarch taught thee insult it need not nor it boot thee not proud queen unless adag must be verifi that beggar mount run their hors death ti beauti that doth oft make women proud but god he know thi share thereof is small ti virtu that doth make them most admir d contrari doth make thee wond red ti govern that make them seem divin want thereof make thee abomin thou art as opposit everi good as antipod are unto us or as south septentrion o tiger s heart wrapp d woman s hide how couldst thou drain life blood child bid father wipe hi eye withal yet be seen bear woman s face women are soft mild piti flexibl thou stern obdur flinti rough remorseless bid st thou me rage whi now thou hast thi wish wouldst have me weep whi now thou hast thi will rage wind blow incess shower when rage allay rain begin these tear are my sweet rutland s obsequi everi drop cri vengeanc hi death gainst thee fell clifford thee fals frenchwoman northumberland beshrew me but hi passion move me so that hardli can i check my eye tear york that face hi hungri cannib would not have touch d would not have stain d blood but you are more inhuman more inexor o ten time more than tiger hyrcania see ruthless queen hapless father s tear thi cloth thou dipp dst blood my sweet boy i tear do wash blood away keep thou napkin go boast thi if thou tell st heavi stori right my soul deer will come thi covert will we make our stand cull princip all deer second keeper i ll stay hill so both may shoot first keeper that cannot be nois thi cross bow will scare herd so my shoot is lost keeper s fee thi is quondam king let s seiz him king henri let me embrac thee sour advers wise men say it is wisest cours second keeper whi linger we let us lay hand him first keeper forbear awhil we ll hear littl more king henri my queen son are gone franc aid as i hear great command warwick is thither gone crave french king s sister wife edward if thi news be true poor queen son your labour is but lost warwick is subtl orat lewi princ soon won move word thi account then margaret may win him she s woman be piti much her sigh will make batt ry hi breast her tear will pierc marbl heart tiger will be mild while she doth mourn nero will be taint remors hear see her plaint her brinish tear ay but she s come beg warwick give she hi left side crave aid henri he hi right ask wife edward she weep say her henri is depo d he smile say hi edward is instal d that she poor wretch grief can speak no more while warwick tell hi titl smooth wrong inferreth argument mighti strength conclus win king her promis hi sister what els strengthen support king edward s place o margaret thu twill be thou poor soul art then forsaken as thou went st forlorn second keeper say what art thou that talk st king queen king henri more than i seem less than i wa born man least less i should not be men may talk king whi not i second keeper ay but thou talk st as if thou wert king king henri whi so i am mind that s enough second keeper but if thou be king where is thi crown king henri my crown is my heart not my head not deck d diamond indian stone not be seen my crown is call d content crown it is that seldom king enjoy second keeper well if you be king crown d content your crown content you must be content go us as we think you are king king edward hath depo d we hi subject sworn all allegi will apprehend you as hi enemi king henri but did you never swear break oath second keeper no never such oath nor will not now king henri where did you dwell when i wa king england second keeper here thi countri where we now remain king henri i wa anoint king nine month old my father my grandfath were king you were sworn true subject unto me tell me then have you not broke your oath first keeper no we were subject but while you were king king henri whi am i dead do i not breath man ah simpl men you know not what you swear look as i blow thi feather my face as air blow it me again obey my wind when i do blow yield anoth when it blow command alway greater gust such is light you common men but do not break your oath that sin my mild entreati shall not make you guilti go where you will king shall be command be you king command i ll obey first keeper we are true subject king king edward king henri so would you be again henri if he were seat as king edward is first keeper we charg you god s name king s go us unto offic king henri god s name lead your king s name be obey d what god will that let your king perform what he will i humbl yield unto exeunt scene ii london palac enter king edward gloucest clarenc ladi grey king edward brother gloucest saint alban field thi ladi s husband sir richard grey wa slain hi land then seiz d conqueror her suit is now repossess those land which we justic cannot well deni becaus quarrel hous york worthi gentleman did lose hi life gloucest your high shall do well grant her suit it were dishonour deni it her king edward it were no less but yet i ll make paus gloucest asid clarenc yea is it so i see ladi hath thing grant king will grant her humbl suit clarenc asid gloucest he know game how true he keep wind gloucest asid clarenc silenc king edward widow we will consid your suit come some other time know our mind ladi grey right graciou lord i cannot brook delay may it pleas your high resolv me now what your pleasur is shall satisfi me gloucest asid ay widow then i ll warrant you all your land if what pleas him shall pleasur you fight closer or good faith you ll catch blow clarenc asid gloucest i fear her not unless she chanc fall gloucest asid clarenc god forbid that he ll take vantag king edward how mani children hast thou widow tell me clarenc asid gloucest i think he mean beg child her gloucest asid clarenc nay then whip me he ll rather give her two ladi grey three my most graciou lord gloucest asid you shall have four if you ll be rul d him king edward twere piti they should lose their father s land ladi grey be piti dread lord grant it then king edward lord give us leav i ll tri thi widow s wit gloucest asid ay good leav have you you will have leav till youth take leav leav you crutch gloucest clarenc withdraw king edward now tell me madam do you love your children ladi grey ay full as dearli as i love myself king edward would you not do much do them good ladi grey do them good i would sustain some harm king edward then get your husband s land do them good ladi grey therefor i came unto your majesti king edward i ll tell you how these land are be got ladi grey so shall you bind me your high servic king edward what servic wilt thou do me if i give them ladi grey what you command that rest me do king edward but you will take except my boon ladi grey no graciou lord i cannot do it king edward ay but thou canst do what i mean ask ladi grey whi then i will do what your grace command gloucest he pli her hard much rain wear marbl clarenc as red as fire nay then her wax must melt ladi grey whi stop my lord shall i not hear my task king edward easi task ti but love king ladi grey that s soon perform d becaus i am subject king edward whi then thi husband s land i freeli give thee ladi grey i take my leav mani thousand thank gloucest match is made she seal it curtsi king edward but stay thee ti fruit love i mean ladi grey fruit love i mean my love lieg king edward ay but i fear me anoth sens what love thinkst thou i sue so much get ladi grey my love till death my humbl thank my prayer that love which virtu beg virtu grant king edward no my troth i did not mean such love ladi grey whi then you mean not as i thought you did king edward but now you partli may perceiv my mind ladi grey my mind will never grant what i perceiv your high aim if i aim aright king edward tell thee plain i aim lie thee ladi grey tell you plain i had rather lie prison king edward whi then thou shalt not have thi husband s land ladi grey whi then mine honesti shall be my dower that loss i will not purchas them king edward therein thou wrong st thi children mightili ladi grey herein your high wrong both them me but mighti lord thi merri inclin accord not sad my suit pleas you dismiss me either ay or no king edward ay if thou wilt say ay my request no if thou dost say no my demand ladi grey then no my lord my suit is end gloucest widow like him not she knit her brow clarenc he is bluntest wooer christendom king edward asid her look doth argu her replet modesti her word doth show her wit incompar all her perfect challeng sovereignti one way or other she is king she shall be my love or els my queen say that king edward take thee hi queen ladi grey ti better said than done my graciou lord i am subject fit jest withal but far unfit be sovereign king edward sweet widow my state i swear thee i speak no more than what my soul intend that is enjoy thee my love ladi grey that is more than i will yield unto i know i am too mean be your queen yet too good be your concubin king edward you cavil widow i did mean my queen ladi grey twill griev your grace my son should call you father king edward no more than when my daughter call thee mother thou art widow thou hast some children god s mother i be but bachelor have other some whi ti happi thing be father unto mani son answer no more thou shalt be my queen gloucest ghostli father now hath done hi shrift clarenc when he wa made shriver twa shrift king edward brother you muse what chat we two have had gloucest widow like it not she look veri sad king edward you d think it strang if i should marri her clarenc who my lord king edward whi clarenc myself gloucest that would be ten day wonder least clarenc that s day longer than wonder last gloucest so much is wonder extrem king edward well jest brother i can tell you both her suit is grant her husband s land enter nobleman nobleman my graciou lord henri your foe is taken brought your prison your palac gate king edward see that he be convey d unto tower go we brother man that took him question hi apprehens widow go you lord use her honour exeunt all but gloucest gloucest ay edward will use women honour would he were wast marrow bone all that hi loin no hope branch may spring cross me golden time i look yet my soul s desir me lust edward s titl buri is clarenc henri hi son young edward all unlook d issu their bodi take their room ere i can place myself cold premedit my purpos whi then i do but dream sovereignti like one that stand promontori spi far off shore where he would tread wish hi foot were equal hi eye chide sea that sunder him thenc say he ll lade it dri have hi way so do i wish crown be so far off so i chide mean that keep me it so i say i ll cut caus off flatter me imposs my eye s too quick my heart o erween too much unless my hand strength could equal them well say there is no kingdom then richard what other pleasur can world afford i ll make my heaven ladi s lap deck my bodi gay ornament witch sweet ladi my word look o miser thought more unlik than accomplish twenti golden crown whi love forswor me my mother s womb i should not deal her soft law she did corrupt frail natur some bribe shrink mine arm like wither d shrub make enviou mountain my back where sit deform mock my bodi shape my leg unequ size disproport me everi part like chao or unlick d bear whelp that carri no impress like dam am i then man be belov d o monstrou fault harbour such thought then thi earth afford no joy me but command check o erbear such as are better person than myself i ll make my heaven dream crown while i live t account thi world but hell my misshap d trunk that bear thi head be round impal gloriou crown yet i know not how get crown mani live stand me home i like one lost thorni wood that rent thorn is rent thorn seek way stray way not know how find open air but toil desper find it torment myself catch english crown that torment i will free myself or hew my way bloodi axe whi i can smile murder while i smile cri content that which griev my heart wet my cheek artifici tear frame my face all occas i ll drown more sailor than mermaid shall i ll slay more gazer than basilisk i ll play orat as well as nestor deceiv more slili than ulyss could like sinon take anoth troy i can add colour chameleon chang shape protheu advantag set murder machiavel school can i do thi cannot get crown tut were it farther off i ll pluck it down exit scene iii franc king s palac flourish enter lewi french king hi sister bona hi admir call d bourbon princ edward queen margaret earl oxford lewi sit riseth again lewi fair queen england worthi margaret sit down us it ill befit thi state birth that thou shouldst stand while lewi doth sit queen margaret no mighti king franc now margaret must strike her sail learn while serv where king command i wa i must confess great albion s queen former golden day but now mischanc hath trod my titl down dishonour laid me ground where i must take like seat unto my fortun my humbl seat conform myself lewi whi say fair queen whenc spring thi deep despair queen margaret such caus as fill mine eye tear stop my tongu while heart is drown d care lewi whate er it be be thou still like thyself sit thee our side seat her him yield not thi neck fortun s yoke but let thi dauntless mind still ride triumph all mischanc be plain queen margaret tell thi grief it shall be ea d if franc can yield relief queen margaret those graciou word reviv my droop thought give my tongu tie sorrow leav speak now therefor be it known nobl lewi that henri sole possessor my love is king becom banish d man forc d live renown queen patienc calm storm while we bethink mean break it off queen margaret more we stay stronger grow our foe lewi more i stay more i ll succour thee queen margaret o but impati waiteth true but right you must all confess that i wa not ignobl descent meaner than myself have had like fortun but as thi titl honour me mine so your dislik whom i would be pleas doth cloud my joy danger sorrow king edward my love forbear fawn their frown what danger or what sorrow can befal thee so long as edward is thi constant friend their true sovereign whom they must obey nay whom they shall obey love thee too unless they seek hatr my hand which if they do yet will i keep thee safe they shall feel vengeanc my wrath gloucest asid i hear yet say not much but think more enter post king edward now warwickshir enter warwick oxford french soldier warwick trust me my lord all hitherto goe well common peopl number swarm us enter clarenc somerset but see where somerset clarenc come speak suddenli my thenc thracian fatal steed so we well cover d night s black mantl unawar may beat down edward s guard seiz himself i say not slaughter him i intend but onli surpris him you that will follow me thi attempt applaud name henri your leader they all cri henri whi then let s our way silent sort warwick hi friend god saint georg exeunt scene iii edward s camp near warwick enter three watchmen guard king s tent first watchman come my master each man take hi stand king thi is set him down sleep second watchman what will he not bed first watchman whi no he hath made solemn vow never lie take hi natur rest till warwick or himself be quit suppress d second watchman morrow then belik shall be day if warwick be so near as men report third watchman but say i pray what nobleman is that that king here resteth hi tent first watchman ti lord hast king s chiefest friend third watchman o is it so but whi command king that hi chief follow lodg town him while he himself keep cold field second watchman ti more honour becaus more danger third watchman ay but give me worship quiet i like it better than danger honour if warwick knew what estat he stand ti be doubt he would waken him first watchman unless our halberd did shut hi passag second watchman ay wherefor els guard we hi royal tent but defend hi person night foe enter warwick clarenc oxford somerset french soldier silent all warwick thi is hi tent see where stand hi guard courag my master honour now or never but follow me edward shall be our first watchman who goe there second watchman stay or thou diest warwick rest cri all warwick warwick set guard who fli cri arm arm warwick rest follow them drum play trumpet sound re enter warwick rest bring king hi gown sit chair gloucest hast fli stage somerset what are they that fli there warwick richard hast let them go here is duke king edward duke whi warwick when we part thou call dst me king warwick ay but case is alter d when you disgrac d me my embassad then i degrad you be king come now creat you duke york ala how should you govern ani kingdom that know not how use ambassador nor how be content one wife nor how use your brother brotherli nor how studi peopl s welfar nor how shroud yourself enemi king edward yea brother clarenc art thou here too nay then i see that edward need must down yet warwick despit all mischanc thee thyself all thi complic edward will alway bear himself as king though fortun s malic overthrow my state my mind exce compass her wheel warwick then hi mind be edward england s king take off hi crown but henri now shall wear english crown be true king inde thou but shadow my lord somerset my request see that forthwith duke edward be convey d unto my brother archbishop york when i have fought pembrok hi fellow i ll follow you tell what answer lewi ladi bona send him now while farewel good duke york king edward what fate impos that men must need abid it boot not resist both wind tide they lead him forcibl oxford what now remain my lord us do but march london our soldier warwick ay that s first thing that we have do free king henri imprison see him seat regal throne exeunt scene iv london palac enter queen elizabeth river river madam what make you thi sudden chang queen elizabeth whi brother river are you yet learn what late misfortun is befal n king edward river what loss some pitch d battl against warwick queen elizabeth no but loss hi own royal person river then is my sovereign slain queen elizabeth ay almost slain he is taken prison either betray d falsehood hi guard or hi foe surpri d unawar as i further have understand is new commit bishop york fell warwick s brother that our foe river these news i must confess are full grief yet graciou madam bear it as you may warwick may lose that now hath won day queen elizabeth till then fair hope must hinder life s decay i rather wean me despair love edward s offspr my womb thi is it that make me bridl passion bear mild my misfortun s cross ay ay thi i draw mani tear stop rise blood suck sigh lest my sigh or tear i blast or drown king edward s fruit true heir th english crown river but madam where is warwick then becom queen elizabeth i am inform d that he come london set crown onc more henri s head guess thou rest king edward s friend must down but prevent tyrant s violenc trust not him that hath onc broken faith i ll henc forthwith unto sanctuari save least heir edward s right there shall i rest secur forc fraud come therefor let us fli while we may fli if warwick take us we are sure die exeunt scene v park near middleham castl king my brother is prison bishop here whose hand he hath good usag great liberti often but attend weak guard come hunt thi way disport himself i have adverti d him secret mean that if thi hour he make thi way colour hi usual game he shall here find hi friend hors men set him free hi captiv enter king edward huntsman him huntsman thi way my lord thi way lie game king edward nay thi way man see where intellig proof as clear as fount juli when we see each grain gravel i do know be corrupt treason norfolk say not treason buckingham th king i ll say t make my vouch as strong as shore rock attend thi i have conscienc let it sink me even as axe fall if i be not faith law i bear no malic my death t ha done premis but justic but those that sought it i could wish more christian be what they will i heartili forgiv em yet let em look they glori not mischief nor build their evil grave great men then my guiltless blood must cri against em further life thi world i ne er hope nor will i sue although me hi grace if he speak buckingham pray tell him you met him half heaven my vow prayer yet are king s till my soul forsak shall cri bless him may he live longer than i have time tell hi year ever belov d love may hi rule be when old time shall lead him hi end good he fill one monument lovel th water side i must conduct your grace then give my charg sir nichola vaux who undertak you your end vaux prepar there duke is come see barg be readi fit it such furnitur as suit great hi person buckingham nay sir nichola let it alon my state now will but mock me when i came hither i wa lord high constabl duke buckingham now poor edward bohun yet i am richer than my base accus that never knew what truth meant i now seal it that blood will make em one day groan fort my nobl father henri buckingham who first rai d head against usurp richard fli succour hi servant banist be distress d wa that wretch betray d trial fell god s peac be him henri seventh succeed truli piti my father s loss like most royal princ restor d me my honour ruin made my name onc more nobl now hi son henri eighth life honour name all that made me happi one stroke ha taken ever world i had my trial must need say nobl one which make me littl happier than my wretch father yet thu far we are one fortun both fell our servant those men we lov d most most unnatur faithless servic heaven ha end all yet you that hear me thi die man receiv as certain where you are liber your love counsel be sure you be not loos those you make friend give your heart when they onc perceiv least rub your fortun fall away like water ye never found again but where they mean sink ye all good peopl pray me i must now forsak ye last hour my long weari life is come me farewel when you would say someth that is sad speak how i fell i have done god forgiv me exeunt buckingham train first gentleman o thi is full piti sir it call i fear too mani curs their head that were author second gentleman if duke be guiltless ti full woe yet i can give you inkl ensu evil if it fall greater than thi first gentleman good angel keep it us what may it be you do not doubt my faith sir second gentleman thi secret is so weighti twill requir strong seem flow him how i th name thrift doe he rake thi togeth now my lord saw you cardin norfolk my lord we have stood here observ him some strang commot is hi brain he bite hi lip start stop sudden look ground then lay hi finger hi templ straight spring fast gait then stop again strike hi breast hard anon he cast hi eye against moon most strang postur we have seen him set himself king it may well be there is mutini s mind thi morn paper state he sent me perus as i requir d wot you what i found there my conscienc put unwittingli forsooth inventori thu import sever parcel hi plate hi treasur rich stuff ornament household which i find such proud rate that it outspeak possess subject norfolk it s heaven s will some spirit put thi paper packet bless your eye withal king if we did think hi contempl were earth fix d spiritu object he should still dwell hi muse but i am afraid hi think are moon not worth hi seriou consid king take hi seat whisper lovel who goe cardin wolsey heaven forgiv me ever god bless your high king good my lord you are full heavenli stuff bear inventori your best grace your mind which you were now run o er you have scarc time steal spiritu leisur brief span keep feebl voic which scorn modern invoc pandulph ladi you utter mad not sorrow constanc thou art not holi beli me so i am not mad thi hair i tear is mine my name is constanc i wa geffrey s wife young cardin be not mad but sensibl grief my reason part produc reason how i may be deliv d these woe teach me kill or hang myself if i were mad i should forget my son or madli think babe clout were he i am not mad too well too well i feel differ plagu each calam king philip bind those tress o what love i note fair multitud those her hair where but chanc silver drop hath fall n even that drop ten thousand wiri friend do glue themselv sociabl grief like true insepar faith love stick togeth calam constanc england if you will king philip bind your hair constanc ye that i will wherefor will i do it i tore them their bond cri aloud o that these hand could so redeem my son as they have given these hair their liberti but now i envi their liberti will again commit them their bond becaus my poor child is prison father cardin i have heard you say that we shall see know our friend heaven if that be true i shall see my boy again birth cain first male child him that did but yesterday suspir there wa not such graciou creatur born but now will canker sorrow eat my bud chase nativ beauti hi cheek he will look as hollow as ghost as dim meagr as agu s fit so he ll die rise so again when i shall meet him court heaven i shall not know him therefor never never must i behold my pretti arthur more pandulph you hold too heinou respect grief constanc he talk me that never had son king philip you are as fond grief as your child constanc grief fill room my absent child lie hi bed walk down me put hi pretti look repeat hi word rememb me all hi graciou part stuff hi vacant garment hi form then have i reason be fond grief fare you well had you such loss as i i could give better comfort than you do i will not keep thi form my head tear her hair when there is such disord my wit o lord my boy my arthur my fair son my life my joy my food my ail world my widow comfort my sorrow cure exit king philip i fear some outrag i ll follow her exit lewi there s noth thi world can make me joy life is as tediou as twice told tale vex dull ear drowsi man bitter shame hath spoil d sweet world s tast that it yield nought but shame bitter pandulph cure strong diseas even instant repair health fit is strongest evil that take leav their departur most all show evil what have you lost lose thi day lewi all day glori joy happi pandulph if you had won it certainli you had no no when fortun mean men most good she look them threat ning eye ti strang think how much king john hath lost thi which he account so clearli won are not you griev d that arthur is hi prison lewi as heartili as he is glad he hath him pandulph your mind is all as youth as your blood now hear me speak prophet spirit even breath what i mean speak shall blow each dust each straw each littl rub path which shall directli lead thi foot england s throne therefor mark john hath seiz d arthur it cannot be that while warm life play that infant s vein misplac d john should entertain hour one minut nay one quiet breath rest sceptr snatch d unruli hand must be boister maintain d as gain d he that stand slipp ry place make nice no vile hold stay him that john may stand then arthur need must fall so be it it cannot be but so lewi but what shall i gain young arthur s fall pandulph you right ladi blanch your wife may then make all claim that arthur did lewi lose it life all as arthur did pandulph how green you are fresh thi old world john lay you plot time conspir you he that steep hi safeti true blood shall find but bloodi safeti untru thi act so evilli born shall cool heart all hi peopl freez their zeal that none so small advantag shall step forth check hi reign but they will cherish it no natur exhal sky no scope natur no distemp d day no common wind no custom event but they will pluck away hi natur caus call them meteor prodigi sign abort presag tongu heaven plainli denounc vengeanc john lewi may be he will not touch young arthur s life but hold himself safe hi prison pandulph o sir when he shall hear your approach if that young arthur be not gone alreadi even that news he die then heart all hi peopl shall revolt him kiss lip unacquaint chang pick strong matter revolt wrath bloodi finger end john can train ten thousand english their side or as littl snow tumbl anon becom mountain o nobl dauphin go me king ti wonder what may be wrought their discont now that their soul are top offenc england go fear night is thi there s two or three us have seen strang sight cassiu am i not stay d tell me cinna ye you are o cassiu if you could but win nobl brutu our parti cassiu be you content good cinna will yet ere day see brutu hi hous three part him is our alreadi man entir next encount yield him our casca o he sit high all peopl s heart that which would appear offenc us hi counten like richest orchard enter brutu brutu what luciu ho i cannot progress star give guess how near day luciu i say i would it were my fault sleep so soundli when luciu when awak i say what luciu enter luciu luciu would be crown d how that might chang hi natur there s question it is bright day that bring forth adder that crave wari walk crown him that then i grant we put sting him that hi will he may do danger th abus great is when it disjoin remors power speak truth caesar i have not known when hi affect sway d more than hi reason but ti common proof that lowli is young ambit s ladder whereto climber upward turn hi face but when he onc attain upmost round he then unto ladder turn hi back look cloud scorn base degre which he did ascend so caesar may then lest he may prevent quarrel will bear no colour thing he is fashion it thu that what he is augment would run these these extrem therefor think him as serpent s egg which hatch d would as hi kind grow mischiev kill him shell enter luciu luciu taper burneth your closet sir search window flint i found thi paper thu seal d i am sure it did not lie there when i went bed _give him letter _ brutu get you bed again it is not day is not tomorrow hand brutu enter luciu luciu sir march is wast fifteen day _knock _ brutu ti good go gate somebodi knock _exit luciu _ cassiu first did whet me against caesar i have not slept act dread thing first here casca no cinna o pardon sir it doth yon grey line that fret cloud are messeng day casca you shall confess that you are both deceiv d here as i point my sword sun aris which is great way grow south weigh youth season year some two month henc higher north he first present hi fire high east stand as capitol directli here brutu give me your hand all one one cassiu let us swear our resolut i am sure they do bear fire enough kindl coward steel valour melt spirit women then countrymen what need we ani spur but our own caus prick us redress what other bond than secret roman that have spoke word will not palter what other oath than honesti honesti engag d that thi shall be or we will fall it swear priest coward men cautel old feebl carrion such suffer soul that welcom wrong unto bad caus leav him cinna no no mean metellu o let us have him hi silver hair will purchas us good opinion buy men s voic commend our deed it shall be said hi judgment rul d our hand our youth wild shall no whit well stretch so far as annoy us all which prevent let antoni caesar fall togeth brutu our cours will seem too bloodi caiu cassiu cut head off then hack limb like wrath death envi afterward antoni is but limb caesar let us be sacrific but not butcher caiu we all stand against spirit caesar spirit men there is no blood o that we then could come caesar s spirit not dismemb caesar but ala caesar must bleed it gentl friend let s kill him boldli but not wrath let s carv him as dish fit god not hew him as carcass fit hound let our heart as subtl master do stir their servant act rage seem chide em thi shall mark our purpos necessari not enviou which so appear common eye we shall be call d purger not murder mark antoni think not him he can do no more than caesar s arm when caesar s head is off cassiu yet i fear him ingraft love he bear caesar brutu ala good cassiu do not think him if he love caesar all that he can do is himself take thought die caesar that were much he should he is given sport wild much compani treboniu there is no fear him let him not die he will live laugh thi hereaft _clock strike _ brutu peac count clock cassiu clock hath stricken three treboniu ti time part cassiu but it is doubt yet caesar will come forth today or no he is superstiti grown late quit main opinion he held onc fantasi dream ceremoni it may be these appar prodigi unaccustom d terror thi night persuas hi augur may hold him capitol today deciu never fear that if he be so resolv i can o ersway him he love hear that unicorn may be betray d tree bear glass eleph hole lion toil men flatter what mean you wherefor rise you now it is not your health thu commit your weak condit raw cold morn portia nor your neither y have ungent brutu stole my bed yesternight supper you suddenli aros walk d muse sigh your arm across when i ask d you what matter wa you star d me ungentl look i urg d you further then you scratch d your head too impati stamp d your foot yet i insist yet you answer d not but angri waftur your hand gave sign me leav you so i did fear strengthen that impati which seem d too much enkindl withal hope it wa but effect humour which sometim hath hi hour everi man it will not let wife i grant i am woman but withal woman well reput cato s daughter think you i am no stronger than my sex be so father d so husband tell me your counsel i will not disclos em i have made strong proof apprehens yet number i do know but one that unassail hold hi rank unshak d motion that i am he let me littl show it even thi that i wa constant cimber should be banish d constant do remain keep him so half that worth as those your sword made rich most nobl blood all thi world i do beseech ye if you bear me hard now whilst your purpl hand do reek smoke fulfil your pleasur live thousand year i shall not find myself so apt die no place will pleas me so no mean death as here caesar you cut off choic master spirit thi age brutu o antoni beg not your death us though now we must appear bloodi cruel as our hand thi our present act you see we do yet see you but our hand thi bleed busi they have done our heart you see not they are piti piti gener wrong rome as fire drive fire so piti piti hath done thi deed caesar your part you our sword have leaden point mark antoni our arm strength malic our heart brother temper do receiv you all kind love good thought rever cassiu your voic shall be as strong domest furi fierc civil strife shall cumber all part itali blood destruct shall be so use dread object so familiar that mother shall but smile when they behold their infant quarter hand war all piti lord _brutu luciliu talk apart _ cassiu messala messala what say my gener cassiu messala thi is my birth day as thi veri day wa cassiu born give me thi hand messala be thou my wit that against my will as pompey wa am i compel d set one battl all our liberti you know that i held epicuru strong hi opinion now i chang my mind partli credit thing that do presag come sardi our former ensign two mighti eagl fell there they perch d gorg feed our soldier hand who philippi here consort us thi morn are they fled away gone their stead do raven crow kite fli o er our head downward look us as we were sickli prey their shadow seem canopi most fatal which our armi lie readi give ghost messala believ not so cassiu i but believ it partli i am fresh spirit resolv d meet all peril veri constantli brutu even so luciliu cassiu now most nobl brutu god today stand friendli that we may lover peac lead our day age but affair men rest still incertain let s reason worst that may befal if we do lose thi battl then is thi veri last time we shall speak togeth what are you then determin do brutu even rule that philosophi which i did blame cato death which he did give himself i know not how but i do find it cowardli vile fear what might fall so prevent time life arm myself patienc stay provid some high power that govern us cassiu then if we lose thi battl you are content be led triumph thorough street rome brutu no cassiu no think not thou nobl roman that ever brutu will go bound rome he bear too great mind but thi same day must end that work ide march begun we shall meet again i know not therefor our everlast farewel take ever ever farewel cassiu if we do meet again whi we shall smile if not whi then thi part wa well made cassiu ever ever farewel brutu if we do meet again we ll smile inde if love him that is honest convers him that is wise say littl fear judgement fight when i cannot choos eat no fish lear what art thou kent veri honest heart fellow as poor as king lear if thou be st as poor subject as he s king thou art poor enough what wouldst thou kent servic lear who wouldst thou serv kent you lear dost thou know me fellow kent no sir but you have that your counten which i would fain call master lear what s that kent author lear what servic canst thou do kent i can keep honest counsel ride run mar curiou tale tell it deliv plain messag bluntli that which ordinari men are fit i am qualifi best me is dilig lear how old art thou kent not so young sir love woman sing nor so old dote her anyth i have year my back forti eight lear follow me thou shalt serv me if i like thee no wors dinner i will not part thee yet dinner ho dinner where s my knave my fool go you call my fool hither _exit attend _ enter oswald you you sirrah where s my daughter oswald so pleas you _exit _ lear what say fellow there call clotpol back _exit knight _ where s my fool ho i think world s asleep re enter knight how now where s that mongrel knight he say my lord your daughter is not well lear whi came not slave back me when i call him knight sir he answer me roundest manner he would not lear he would not knight my lord i know not what matter is but my judgement your high is not entertain that ceremoni affect as you were wont there s great abat kind appear as well gener depend as duke himself also your daughter lear ha say st thou so knight i beseech you pardon me my lord if i be mistaken my duti cannot be silent when i think your high wrong lear thou but rememberest me mine own concept i have perceiv most faint neglect late which i have rather blame as mine own jealou curios than as veri pretenc purpos unkind i will look further t but where s my fool i have not seen him thi two day knight my young ladi s go franc sir fool hath much pine away lear no more that i have note it well go you tell my daughter i would speak her _exit attend _ go you call hither my fool _exit anoth attend _ re enter oswald o you sir you come you hither sir who am i sir oswald my ladi s father s dog must kennel he must be whip when ladi brach may stand fire stink lear pestil gall me fool sirrah i ll teach thee speech lear do fool mark it nuncl have more than thou showest speak less than thou knowest lend less than thou owest ride more than thou goest learn more than thou trowest set less than thou throwest leav thi drink thi whore keep door thou shalt have more than two ten score thi is not altogeth fool my lord fool no faith lord great men will not let me if i had monopoli they would have part t ladi too they will not let me have all fool myself they ll be snatch nuncl give me egg i ll give thee two crown lear what two crown shall they be fool whi i have cut egg i middl eat meat two crown egg when thou clovest thi crown i middl gav st away both part thou bor st thine ass thi back o er dirt thou hadst littl wit thi bald crown when thou gav st thi golden one away if i speak like myself thi let him be whip that first find it so _sing _ fool had ne er less grace year wise that show d my duti kneel came there reek post stew d hi hast half breathless pant forth goneril hi mistress salut deliv d letter spite intermiss which present they read those content they summon d their meini straight took hors command me follow attend leisur their answer gave me cold look meet here other messeng whose welcom i perceiv d had poison d mine be veri fellow which late display d so saucili against your high have more man than wit me drew he rai d hous loud coward cri your son daughter found thi trespass worth shame which here it suffer fool winter s not gone yet if wild gees fli that way father that wear rag do make their children blind but father that bear bag shall see their children kind fortun that arrant whore ne er turn key th poor but all thi thou shalt have as mani dolour thi daughter as thou canst tell year lear o how thi mother swell my heart _hysterica passio_ down thou climb sorrow thi element s where is thi daughter kent earl sir here lear follow me not stay here _exit _ gentleman made you no more offenc but what you speak kent none how chanc king come so small number fool thou hadst been set i stock that question thou hadst well deserv it kent whi fool fool we ll set thee school ant teach thee there s no labour i winter all that follow their nose are led their eye but blind men there s not nose twenti but can smell him that s stink let go thi hold when great wheel run down hill lest it break thi neck follow it but great one that goe upward let him draw thee when wise man give thee better counsel give me mine again i would have none but knave follow it fool give it that sir which serv seek gain follow but form will pack when it begin rain leav thee storm but i will tarri fool will stay let wise man fli knave turn fool that run away daughter speak command tend servic are they inform d thi my breath blood fieri fieri duke tell hot duke that no but not yet mayb he is not well infirm doth still neglect all offic whereto our health he sit here thi act persuad me that thi remot duke her is practic onli give me my servant forth go tell duke s wife i d speak them now present bid them come forth hear me or their chamber door i ll beat drum till it cri sleep death gloucest i would have all well betwixt you _exit _ lear o me my heart my rise heart but down fool cri it nuncl as cockney did eel when she put em i past aliv she knap if sir perchanc she have restrain d riot your follow ti such ground such wholesom end as clear her all blame lear my curs her regan o sir you are old natur you stand veri verg her confin you should be rul d led some discret that discern your state better than you yourself therefor i pray you that our sister you do make return say you have wrong d her sir lear ask her forgiv do you but mark how thi becom hous dear daughter i confess that i am old _kneel _ age is unnecessari my knee i beg that you ll vouchsaf me raiment bed food regan good sir no more these are unsightli trick return you my sister lear _rise _ never regan she hath abat me half my train look d black me struck me her tongu most serpent like veri heart all stor d vengeanc heaven fall her ingrat top strike her young bone you take air lame cornwal fie sir fie lear you nimbl lightn dart your blind flame her scorn eye infect her beauti you fen suck d fog drawn power sun fall blast her pride regan o blest god so will you wish me when rash mood is lear no regan thou shalt never have my curs thi tender heft natur shall not give thee o er harsh her eye are fierc but thine do comfort not burn ti not thee grudg my pleasur cut off my train bandi hasti word scant my size conclus oppos bolt against my come thou better know st offic natur bond childhood effect courtesi due gratitud thi half o kingdom hast thou not forgot wherein i thee endow d regan good sir purpos lear who put my man i stock _tucket _ cornwal what trumpet s that regan i know t my sister s thi approv her letter that she would soon be here enter oswald is your ladi come lear thi is slave whose easi borrow pride dwell fickl grace her he follow varlet my sight cornwal what mean your grace lear who stock d my servant regan i have good hope thou didst not know t who come here o heaven enter goneril if you do love old men if your sweet sway allow obedi if yourselv are old make it your caus send down take my part _to goneril _ art not asham d look thi beard o regan wilt thou take her hand goneril whi not hand sir how have i offend all s not offenc that indiscret find dotag term so lear o side you are too tough will you yet hold how came my man i stock cornwal i set him there sir but hi own disord deserv d much less advanc lear you did you regan i pray you father be weak seem so if till expir your month you will return sojourn my sister dismiss half your train come then me i am now home that provis which shall be need your entertain lear return her fifti men dismiss d no rather i abjur all roof choos wage against enmiti o air be comrad wolf owl necess s sharp pinch return her whi hot blood franc that dowerless took our youngest born i could as well be brought knee hi throne squir like pension beg keep base life afoot return her persuad me rather be slave sumpter thi detest groom _point oswald _ goneril your choic sir lear i prythe daughter do not make me mad i will not troubl thee my child farewel we ll no more meet no more see one anoth but yet thou art my flesh my blood my daughter or rather diseas that s my flesh which i must need call mine thou art boil plagu sore or emboss carbuncl my corrupt blood but i ll not chide thee let shame come when it will i do not call it i do not bid thunder bearer shoot nor tell tale thee high judg jove mend when thou canst be better thi leisur i can be patient i can stay regan i my hundr knight regan not altogeth so i look d not you yet nor am provid your fit welcom give ear sir my sister those that mingl reason your passion must be content think you old so but she know what she doe lear is thi well spoken regan i dare avouch it sir what fifti follow is it not well what should you need more yea or so mani sith that both charg danger speak gainst so great number how one hous should mani peopl two command hold amiti ti hard almost imposs goneril whi might not you my lord receiv attend those that she call servant or mine regan whi not my lord if then they chanc d slack ye we could control them if you will come me now i spi danger i entreat you bring but five twenti no more will i give place or notic lear i gave you all regan good time you gave it lear made you my guardian my depositari but kept reserv be follow such number what must i come you five twenti regan said you so regan speak t again my lord no more me lear those wick creatur yet do look well favour d when other are more wick not be worst stand some rank prais _to goneril _ i ll go thee thi fifti yet doth doubl five twenti thou art twice her love goneril hear me my lord what need you five twenti ten or five follow hous where twice so mani have command tend you regan what need one lear o reason not need our basest beggar are poorest thing superflu allow not natur more than natur need man s life is cheap as beast s thou art ladi if onli go warm were gorgeou whi natur need not what thou gorgeou wear st which scarc keep thee warm but true need you heaven give me that patienc patienc i need you see me here you god poor old man as full grief as age wretch both if it be you that stir these daughter heart against their father fool me not so much bear it tame touch me nobl anger let not women s weapon water drop stain my man s cheek no you unnatur hag i will have such reveng you both that all world shall i will do such thing what they are yet i know not but they shall be terror earth you think i ll weep no i ll not weep _storm tempest _ i have full caus weep but thi heart shall break hundr thousand flaw or ere i ll weep o fool i shall go mad _exeunt lear gloucest kent fool _ cornwal let us withdraw twill be storm regan thi hous is littl old man hi peopl cannot be well bestow d goneril ti hi own blame hath put himself rest must need tast hi folli regan hi particular i ll receiv him gladli but not one follow goneril so am i purpo d where is my lord gloucest enter gloucest cornwal follow old man forth he is return d gloucest king is high rage cornwal whither is he go gloucest he call hors but will i know not whither cornwal ti best give him way he lead himself goneril my lord entreat him no mean stay gloucest alack night come high wind do sore ruffl mani mile there s scarc bush regan o sir wil men injuri that they themselv procur must be their schoolmast shut your door he is attend desper train what they may incens him be apt have hi ear abu d wisdom bid fear cornwal shut your door my lord ti wild night my regan counsel well come o storm _exeunt _ act iii scene i heath storm thunder lightn enter kent gentleman sever kent who s there besid foul weather gentleman one mind like weather most unquietli kent i know you where s king gentleman contend fret element bid wind blow earth sea or swell curl water bove main that thing might chang or ceas tear hi white hair which impetu blast eyeless rage catch their furi make noth strive hi littl world man outscorn fro conflict wind rain thi night wherein cub drawn bear would couch lion belli pinch wolf keep their fur dri unbonnet he run bid what will take all kent but who is him gentleman none but fool who labour jest hi heart struck injuri kent sir i do know you dare warrant my note commend dear thing you there is divis although as yet face it be cover d mutual cun twixt albani cornwal who have as who have not that their great star throne d set high servant who seem no less which are franc spi specul intellig our state what hath been seen either snuff pack duke or hard rein which both them have born against old kind king or someth deeper whereof perchanc these are but furnish but true it is franc there come power thi scatter d kingdom who alreadi wise our neglig have secret feet some our best port are point show their open banner now you if my credit you dare build so far make your speed dover you shall find some that will thank you make just report how unnatur bemad sorrow king hath caus plain i am gentleman blood breed some knowledg assur offer thi offic you gentleman i will talk further you kent no do not confirm that i am much more than my wall open thi purs take what it contain if you shall see cordelia as fear not but you shall show her thi ring she will tell you who your fellow is that yet you do not know fie thi storm i will go seek king gentleman give me your hand have you no more say kent few word but effect more than all yet that when we have found king which your pain that way i ll thi he that first light him holla other _exeunt _ scene ii anoth part heath storm continu enter lear fool lear blow wind crack your cheek rage blow you cataract hurricano spout till you have drench d our steepl drown d cock you sulphur thought execut fire vaunt courier oak cleav thunderbolt sing my white head thou all shake thunder strike flat thick rotund o world crack natur s mould all germen spill onc that make ingrat man fool o nuncl court holi water dri hous is better than thi rain water o door good nuncl ask thi daughter bless here s night piti neither wise men nor
